artist: Artist: Utagawa Kunisada; Publisher: Tsujiokaya Bunsuke; Carver: Yokogawa Takejirō; Printer: Ōumiya Hisatarō
creditline: Bequest of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
description: portrait of man with long frowning face and large nose, wearing bolding patterned garments including blue with bold white floral outlines and brown with white checks; man wears a with cloth tied around his neck; water scene behind man with cluster of docked sailboats, trees in ULQ and bridge with figures along right edge in URQ
markings: date seal: 子閏 {ne urū} (Rat intercalary) | censor seals: 福 {Fuku} | 村松 {Muramatsu} | carver\'s seal: 彫竹 {hori Take} | printer\'s seal:  摺大久 {suri Ōhisa} | publisher\'s seal: 文　辻岡屋 {Bun, Tsujiokaya}
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Fifty-Three Stations along the Tōkaidō with Visual Parodies of Actors (Yakusha mitate Tōkaidō gojūsan tsugi 役者見立東海道五十三驛)
signed: in toshidama cartouche: 豊國画 {Toyokuni ga}
text: The actor Matsumoto Kōshirō V (1764-1838) is captured as the chivalrous townsman Banzui Chōbei after arriving in his palanquin at Suzugamori, the execution ground of Edo near Shinagawa, where the handsome murderer Shirai Gonpachi is being attacked by a band of robbers. After Gonpachi defeats them with his elegant swordsmanship, Chōbei approaches Gonpachi. This is the right sheet of a pseudo-diptych; the left shows the actor Iwai Tojaku (1776-1847) as Shirai Gonpachi, juxtaposed to the station Kawasaki.
title: Shinagawa Station; Actor Matsumoto Kōshirō V as Banzui Chōbei
